qas.question: What species group are annelids' muscle control similar to?

answers.text: the output signal lines of nerve cells

qas.question: How do annelids withdraw from danger?
What species group are annelids' mind control similar to?

plausible_answers.text: the output signal lines of nerve cells

qas.question: What worms are very slow to retreat from danger?

context: As in <a0_0><b3_0>arthropods<b3_0/><a0_0/>, each muscle fiber (cell) is controlled by more than one neuron, and the speed and power of the fiber's contractions depends on the combined effects of all its neurons. Vertebrates have a different system, in which one neuron controls a group of muscle fibers. Most <b6_0>annelids<b6_0/>' longitudinal nerve trunks include giant axons (<a1_0><b4_0>the output signal lines of nerve cells<b4_0/><a1_0/>). Their large diameter decreases their resistance, which allows them to transmit signals exceptionally fast. This enables these worms to withdraw rapidly from danger by <a2_0><b5_0>shortening their bodies<b5_0/><a2_0/>. Experiments have shown that cutting the giant axons prevents this escape response but does not affect normal movement.
